newsitem.title: USA: St. Paul council approves $30 mln for arena -- paper.
newsitem.headline: St. Paul council approves $30 mln for arena -- paper.

text.p: St. Paul City Council Wednesday approved a plan to contribute $30 million toward a new downtown arena with an eye toward luring a National Hockey League expansion franchise, Star Tribune reported Thursday.
The council voted 6-1 to approve the city's contribution toward a $130 million arena, the newspaper said.
Minnesota legislators would still have to approve another $65 million for the arena, which would also be financed partly by the investment group leading the expansion bid.

St. Paul is one of six cities that are finalists for the next round of expansion. The NHL expansion committee has visited all the finalists, but has not announced when it will expand, or how many franchises will be added to the league.
The NHL board of governors meets next on Friday. Groups from Atlanta, Columbus, Houston, Nashville and Oklahoma City are also among the finalists.
The failure of a sales tax referendum in Columbus on Tuesday effectively eliminates that city from the competition, supporters of an expansion bid there have said.
Minnesota Gov. Arne Carlson has pledged his support to issue up to $65 million of bonds for the new arena, which would be built on the site of the existing Civic Center.
St. Paul officials plan to recover their contribution to the arena through $1.8 million in arena advertising revenue and a $1 per ticket surcharge, the Star Tribune reported.
